channel.description: Recent content in go on maelvls.dev

item.title: You should write comments
item.description: We often talk about avoiding unecessary comments that needlessly paraphrase what the code does. In this article, I gathered some thoughts about why writing comments is as important as writing the code itself.

item.title: What to do when Go ignores HTTP_PROXY for 127.0.0.1
item.description: At some point, the Go team chose to disable the proxy for requests coming from localhost or 127.0.0.1. This is annoying when debugging services locally.

item.title: Go Happy Path: the Unindented Line of Sight
item.description: Readability is a properly we all love about Go. In other languages, it might be fine to have a lot of nested if statements; in Go, it is a good practice to keep away from overly-nested logic.

item.title: GO111MODULE is everywhere: history and tips
item.description: GO111MODULE is all over the place. It appears in README install instructions, in Dockerfiles, in makefiles. On top of that, the behavior of GO111MODULE has changed from Go 1.11 to 1.12, changed again with 1.13 and will changed a last time in 1.14.

item.title: Use of conditions in Kubernetes controllers
item.description: Although progress is being made, Kubernetes controllers and operators still require prior knowledge about Kubernetes internals. Information on how to set the status is scattered across comments, issues, PRs and the Kubernetes code itself. Conditions may be a good solution for your controller, but for what?
